thread.title: Graham Norton doesn't seem that optimistic that UK will win Eurovision 2017
thread.title_full: Graham Norton doesn't seem that optimistic that UK will win Eurovision 2017

author: Vicki Newman
title: Graham Norton doesn't seem that optimistic that UK will win Eurovision 2017
text:
Graham Norton doesn't seem that optimistic that UK will win Eurovision 2017 Lucie Jones beat five other hopefuls for the chance to compete in the famous singing contest Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Lucie Jones to represent the UK at Eurovision Share this video Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Graham Norton doesn’t seem overly optimistic about the UK’s chances of winning Eurovision 2017 . 
The show’s commentator, 53, has admitted it’s probably unlikely our representative this year, Lucie Jones, will break our unlucky streak at the annual singing competition, even if he's fully backing her to do us all proud. 
“I’m just not sure it will happen for us this year. I mean, I could be wrong as Germany have won, Austria have won. So I suppose people who never win, win,” he said. 
“On the night anything can happen. I’m just not sure it will for us though,” he added to Daily Star . Graham is the Eurovision commentator (Photo: BBC) Lucie Jones will represent the UK (Photo: BBC) Read More BBC pay ultimate tribute to Terry Wogan by naming building he hosted Radio 2 show after him 
Eurovision 2017 takes place in Kiev, Ukraine on May 13. 
Though - like all of us - Graham will be keeping his fingers crossed that Lucie could be the first UK act since Katrina and the Waves back in 1997 to take home the prize. 
When he chatted to her on his BBC Radio 2 show, he said: “I think once you say I’m doing this, I think it’s really important people get behind you and support you.” 
He then said: “Her name is Lucie Jones, we must all now support her.” 
Former X Factor contestant Lucie won the chance to represent the United Kingdom at the Eurovision Song Contest 2017 after beating the five other hopefuls on Eurovision: You Decide. 
Each of the contestants had previously appeared on The X Factor . 
On the show, hosted by Mel Giedroyc, they each sang for an expert panel, made up of Bruno Tonioli, Sophie Ellis-Bextor and CeCe Sammy. 
Mel described it as the "single most important decision of the year", before holding her finger to her earpiece to say she'd had confirmation that she wasn't over-exagerating. Read More Who is Lucie Jones? X Factor contestant turned Eurovision Song Contest 2017 hopeful Lucie was crowned winner (Photo: BBC) 
But it was Lucie who impressed the judges the most with her rendition of Never Give Up On You. 
Holly Brewer was up first with I Wish I Loved You More. 
The singer, who admitted she'd "love to be a pop diva", said that representing her country in the competition would be a "dream come true". 
CeCe said her song was "beautiful", while Bruno said it was "elegant" until she belted it out at the end. 
Sophie said the song was "fresh" and had gone down "really well". 
Danyl Johnson took to the stage next with Light Up The World. Lucie beat five hopefuls to the top prize (Photo: BBC) Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
